messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

messages.name: get_code_snippet
get_code_snippet

messages.content:
Title: Diagnosis of test `testLang882`
Details: The test `testLang882` tests the `translate` method of the `LookupTranslator` class in the `org.apache.commons.lang3.text.translate` package. The test sets up a `LookupTranslator` instance with a single mapping from `"one"` to `"two"`. It then calls the `translate` method with the input `"one"`, and expects the result to be `3`. However, the test fails with the error message "Incorrect codepoint consumption expected:<3> but was:<0>".

By examining the code of the `LookupTranslator` class, we can see that the `translate` method loops through different sub-sequences of the input in descending order of length. It tries to find a matching sub-sequence in the lookup map, and if a match is found, it writes the corresponding value to the output writer and returns the length of the sub-sequence. However, in this case, the loop is not executed at all because the `max` variable is set to `0`.

Looking at the constructor of the `LookupTranslator` class, we can see that the `shortest` and `longest` member variables are initialized with `Integer.MAX_VALUE` and `0` respectively. These variables are used to determine the valid range of sub-sequence lengths in the `translate` method. However, based on the provided code snippet, we cannot determine the values of the `lookup` array passed to the constructor, which is used to populate the `lookupMap` map. The issue may lie in the initialization of the `shortest` and `longest` variables, or in the logic of the loop in the `translate` method.

To diagnose the issue further, we would need to analyze the complete code implementation of the `LookupTranslator` class and the values passed to its constructor.

Suggested fixes:
- `org.apache.commons.lang3.text.translate.LookupTranslator.LookupTranslator(java.lang.CharSequence[]...)`
- `org.apache.commons.lang3.text.translate.LookupTranslator.translate(java.lang.CharSequence, int, java.io.Writer)`

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
